fields.description:
Currently Bamboo database gets changed randomly, and when users have some custom developed tools, there is chance that they will break when there are changed in the DB schema. It would be great to document Bamboo DB (tables, connections and logic behind them) and maintain the changes for each release. 

This will be helpful not only for users, but also for Atlassian Support.
fields.summary: Create a public Bamboo Database documentation and maintain it for every new release
Create documentation regarding IAM permissions needed to integrate Elastic Bamboo with AWS.

fields.description:
Our passwords are generated by Amazon AWS and contain characters like '/' or '+'. We have no control over the character set used to generate the passwords.

Bamboo will fail to hide the password in the log if they contain one of the mentioned characters.
fields.summary: Password variables are visible in log if they contain characters like '/' or '+'
Discrepency between testCollationService.collateTestResults javadoc and implementation

fields.description:
If a git checkout task fails, it will clean the directory and retry in a different way.  

{noformat}
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:20	Starting task 'Checkout Confluence' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs:task.vcs.checkout'
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:20	Updating source code to revision: ea660f5884491b461735c91a59cd6b64aae103eb
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:20	Creating local git repository in '/opt/bamboo-agent/xml-data/build-dir/COD-CODAT-ALCCLIENT01/.git'.
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:20	Initialized empty Git repository in /opt/bamboo-agent/xml-data/build-dir/COD-CODAT-ALCCLIENT01/.git/
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:20	Fetching 'refs/heads/master' from 'https://address.to.my/repo.git'. Will try to do a shallow fetch.
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:36	From https://address.to.my/repo.git
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:36	 * [new branch]      master     -> master
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:36	Checking out revision ea660f5884491b461735c91a59cd6b64aae103eb.
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:36	fatal: reference is not a tree: ea660f5884491b461735c91a59cd6b64aae103eb
error	02-Dec-2013 04:40:36	Checkout to revision ea660f5884491b461735c91a59cd6b64aae103eb has failed.
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:36	Warning: failed to checkout source code to directory '/opt/bamboo-agent/xml-data/build-dir/COD-CODAT-ALCCLIENT01', trying to recover...
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:36	Cleaned source directory '/opt/bamboo-agent/xml-data/build-dir/COD-CODAT-ALCCLIENT01'...
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:36	Creating local git repository in '/opt/bamboo-agent/xml-data/build-dir/COD-CODAT-ALCCLIENT01/.git'.
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:36	Initialized empty Git repository in /opt/bamboo-agent/xml-data/build-dir/COD-CODAT-ALCCLIENT01/.git/
simple	02-Dec-2013 04:40:37	Fetching 'refs/heads/master' from 'https://address.to.my/repo.git'
{noformat}

See the "Warning: failed to checkout source code to directory '/opt/bamboo-agent/xml-data/build-dir/COD-CODAT-ALCCLIENT01', trying to recover..." message.

The problem is: if you downloaded an artifact to the same directory, you will silently lose your artifact. It's fairly easy to make that mistake if you place the artifact and the source at the root level (the default values). 

It was a shared repository, shallow clones enabled.
fields.summary: Git checkout failure should keep the build shared artifacts
Upgrade to Amazon Linux 2014.03

fields.description:
createInitialVolume.sh and generateSnapshot.sh are not specifying region when calling EC2 CLI tools, so these scripts does not work when elastic bamboo is configured for non-default region.

I tried to set AWS_DEFAULT_REGION environment variable before running these scripts - this did not help.
fields.summary: createInitialVolume.sh and generateSnapshot.sh does not respect Elastic Bamboo AWS region

fields.description:
I've got a Maven3 builder, and I'm passing in environment variables based on Bamboo global variables.

For example, I pass in this value:
{code}
AWS_ACCESS_KEY=${bamboo.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_PASSWORD}
{code}

The value is then visible in the logs, unmasked. E.g, the logs contain a line like this:

{code}
/opt/maven-3.0/bin/mvn -Djava.io.tmpdir=/tmp/MYPROJECT-JOB1 clean verify enforcer:enforce --batch-mode
 ... in: /mnt/bamboo-ebs/bamboo-agent/build-dir/MYPROJECT-JOB1
  ... using extra environment variables: 
  MAVEN2_HOME=/opt/maven-3.0
  JAVA_HOME=/opt/jdk-7
  useMavenReturnCode=false
  AWS_ACCESS_KEY=AKIA<rest deleted by me;should be masked>
  bamboo_AWS_SECRET_KEY_PASSWORD=********
  M2_HOME=/opt/maven-3.0
  bamboo_AWS_ACCESS_KEY_PASSWORD=********
  bamboo_recipe_name=iespersist_service
  AWS_SECRET_KEY=MTFt<rest deleted by me;should be masked>
  PATH=<truncated>
  {code}

The "bamboo_" prefixed variables are masked, but I don't want to use the bamboo prefix in my build scripts and test code (Yeah, I'm fussy that way). The variables I've manually added are _not_ masked.
fields.summary: PASSWORD environment variables passed to build scripts are not masked

fields.description:
It would be great to have the possibility to rollback a deployment.

Sometimes, after a deployment was executed, something went wrong and they is no other possibility to rollback a deployment.

After we have utilized our deployment pipeline(deploy release, rollback release), we plan to use Bamboo as CI-Server and control the deployments and rollbacks through the GUI, but i see no possibility to run a rollback!
fields.summary: Rollback a deployment

case:
1. running plan
2. a user with a special character e.g. Noël commits to git
3. plan is not running anymore

stacktrace: (see attachment)

java.lang.RuntimeException: Could not create a new author record for committer 'Noël Bossart <email>'
...
Caused by: org.springframework.dao.DataIntegrityViolationException: Hibernate operation: Could not execute JDBC batch update; SQL []; Violation of UNIQUE KEY constraint 'author_author_name_key'. Cannot insert duplicate key in object 'dbo.AUTHOR'.; nested exception is java.sql.BatchUpdateException: Violation of UNIQUE KEY constraint 'author_author_name_key'. Cannot insert duplicate key in object 'dbo.AUTHOR'.
...


if i delete all entries from dbo.AUTHOR, the plan will create two new ones and run into the same problem again.
fields.summary: can't run plan if a user with a special character in name commits to a git repo

fields.description:
If a repository is deleted in Bitbucket, the Build configuration page in Bamboo will not allow you to change repositories or add new ones until the old repository is deleted.

When a deleted Repository is present and viewed, a Bitbucket error window is shown in the Repository Details pane. Once this error is shown subsequent requests will be made as this:
{{https://base_url/chain/admin/config/%CONTEXT_PATH%/rest/hg/latest/bb/repositories/username/}}
This will cause a 400 bad request error, as the proper format for the request is:
{{https://base_url/rest/hg/latest/bb/repositories/username/}}

*Steps to Reproduce*
# Create a new Repository on Bitbucket
# Create a new Plan on Bamboo
# Add a repository, select *Bitbucket* from the dropdown list
# Select the Repository you just created
# Save the Repo configuration
# On Bitbucket, delete the Repository
# Refresh the Plan configuration page, and click on your repository to view its details.

*Result* 
An error is shown on the page and the Layout of the page changes (it no longer fills the screen horizontally
!BB-error.jpg|thumbnail!

* Try adding a new Repository, this will always return a '400 bad request error'

*Workaround*
Delete the Repository in Bamboo, wait a while (several minutes) for the change to be picked up, Refresh the page then add a new one.
fields.summary: When a Bitbucket Repository is deleted, a 400 Bad Request error is shown when trying to edit repositories

fields.description:
I have 49 unit tests based on PHP unit.
Sometimes testplan with 2 tests failed because of precondition error (bug in setUpBeforeClass). In this case Bamboo shows me 47 tests success, 0/47 tests failed, and sends me a letter with red color of test JOB with message of failed JOB (same situation in Panel - everything success but JOB is failed and red colored).
It confuses a lot. No warnings that 2 of 49 tests cannot be completed because of precondition error. Sometimes it takes a lot of time to realize that we should investigate full execution log to find this "Tests: 47, Assertions: 99, Errors: 2."
Please show us the ERRORS tests (not failed!) in Bamboo test results. It will safe the time.

Thanx a lot.
fields.summary: PHPUnit test results when precondition is failed

fields.description:
I'm using Maven version 3.1.1 with Bamboo & Stash/Git. My Git-repository has the tags [project]\-2.0.0 up to [project]\-4.0.3. Running the build-/release-plan yields the following error: 

build	28-Nov-2013 07:25:21	[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-release-plugin:2.3.2:prepare (default-cli) on project [project]: Unable to tag SCM
build	28-Nov-2013 07:25:21	[ERROR] Provider message:
build	28-Nov-2013 07:25:21	[ERROR] The git-tag command failed.
build	28-Nov-2013 07:25:21	[ERROR] Command output:
build	28-Nov-2013 07:25:21	[ERROR] fatal: tag '[project]-4.0.4' already exists

I checked roughly 12 times and I'm 100% sure, that the tag in question does not exist in the git-repository. Is this a bug or am I doing something wrong?
fields.summary: mvn release:prepare thinks tag already exists

fields.description:
{noformat}
bamboo=> select * from HIBERNATE_UNIQUE_KEY;
next_hi 
---------
    2253
    2253
    2253
    2253
    2253
    2492
    2235
    2235
(8 rows)
{noformat}

This is the table Hibernate uses to generate unique keys for database rows via the [Hilo algorithm|http://stackoverflow.com/questions/282099/whats-the-hi-lo-algorithm]. It should only have one row, but in our case it had 8. This caused hibernate to generate a duplicate key, causing a {{DataIntegrityViolationException}}.

Our specific symptom was:

{noformat}
org.springframework.dao.DataIntegrityViolationException: Hibernate operation: Could not execute JDBC batch update; SQL []; Batch entry 0 insert into USER_COMMIT (REPOSITORY_CHANGESET_ID, AUTHOR_ID, COMMIT_DATE, COMMIT_REVISION, COMMIT_COMMENT_CLOB, COMMIT_ID) values ('73629697', '70516741', '2013-11-27 19:43:57.523000 -06:00:00', '17308', 'DRC-755 : added the class to the serializer

-Pushyami', '73662465') was aborted.  Call getNextException to see the cause.; nested exception is java.sql.BatchUpdateException: Batch entry 0 insert into USER_COMMIT (REPOSITORY_CHANGESET_ID, AUTHOR_ID, COMMIT_DATE, COMMIT_REVISION, COMMIT_COMMENT_CLOB, COMMIT_ID) values ('73629697', '70516741', '2013-11-27 19:43:57.523000 -06:00:00', '17308', 'DRC-755 : added the class to the serializer

-Pushyami', '73662465') was aborted.  Call getNextException to see the cause.
...
...
...
2013-11-27 20:42:43,369 WARN [3-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-6-thread-1] [JDBCExceptionReporter] SQL Error: 0, SQLState: 23505
2013-11-27 20:42:43,369 ERROR [3-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-6-thread-1] [JDBCExceptionReporter] ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "user_commit_pkey"
  Detail: Key (commit_id)=(73662465) already exists.
{noformat}

This caused the build to error out at the beginning of the build during an SVN update.

However, this could theoretically happen on any table update that relies on Hibernate generating unique keys.

I've attached debug logs where the exception occurred, but it's not clear how {{HIBERNATE_UNIQUE_KEY}} got into this state.
fields.summary: HIBERNATE_UNIQUE_KEY has multiple entries

fields.description:
The "Detect Server Capabilities" feature in Bamboo is currently able to detect Visual Studio 2010 (VS100COMNTOOLS) and Visual Studio 2008 (VS90COMNTOOLS). Please make it possible to have VS 2012 and VS 2013 automatically detected also:
Visual Studio 2012 (Visual Studio 11) - VS110COMNTOOLS
Visual Studio 2013 (Visual Studio 12) - VS120COMNTOOLS
fields.summary: Make the detect server capabilities feature able to find Visual Studio 2012/2013

fields.description:
We don't want to use the checkbox to 'Clean working directory after each build' because often a plan runs each hour and this would mean all the artifacts would need to be downloaded again.

Reason - Teams often checkout from a tag, thus if they release every 2 weeks (typical scrum), they get a new directory structure within there plans build-dir - due to the changed tag name. 

So I'm hoping to clean up the older working directory names - NOT the current one (else next hour the binaries would have to be downloaded again!).

It should have flexibility just like Build Expiry Rules.
fields.summary: Add functionality to clean build directories similar to build expiry

fields.description:
When you have several branches within a repository these can be built using branch builds of the same build plan. This is great until the requirement for one or more of the branches change.

For example, we recently upgraded one of our applications from Visual Studio 2010 to Visual Studio 2013 and this new version is maintained on a separate branch.

We would like to have the capability to create a branch build and override the requirements for a task.
fields.summary: Modify requirements for tasks in a branch build

fields.description:
Scenario:
- Build on 2 branches
-- master
-- offline
-  2 Environments for deployment from those branches

What happens: a deploy from a non-main branch uses default versioning in the format of current branch and the build number. Only a deploy that has master set as a branch will use the actual versioning that is defined.

Note: 2nd environment and branch was added later.
fields.summary: Branch deployment doesn't follow release versioning

1. Break existing build by deleting a user with ssh keys setup in stash.
2. Try to fix build by editing the credentials in the bamboo source repository setup. (In my case new credentials were that of the ssh access key I'd added)
3. Re-run failed build (instead of starting a new build)

fields.description:
We have a simple bamboo plan that checks out a svn directory and then executes maven.
However, it seems that if (for any reason), svn cannot update a previous svn workspace,
it just logs this with a "error: has been skipped due to conflict in its contents status",
and it continues to build the plan (maven in our case).

This is *very* dangerous!
It means that a build plan can appear as green when it actually didn't test the complete svn trunk!
Or that you can make a release with a non-updated svn trunk!

A bamboo plan has the option "source code checkout" -> Force Clean Build: false/true
  Removes the source directory and checks it out again prior to each build. This may significantly increase build times.

Activating that option would about this option, but it would slow down the build time.
Moreover, this option cannot be activated by default on *all* bamboo plans.

How can we tell bamboo to *stop* and fail building a plan if svn cannot update a previous svn workspace?
That is, how can we tell bamboo that instead of just showing this message "error: has been skipped due to conflict in its contents status",
it stops and fails?

this is a severe issue!

{code}

simple	22-Nov-2013 14:16:36	Build working directory is /atlassian/bamboo/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/MYPLAN-JOB1

fields.description:
In some cases when using cvs repository, bamboo occasionally throw the error "it was marked as in progress but no agents were assigned to it." This does not affect the build as it continues to run successfully. The build is affected in some other way like artifacts not published.

There is most likely a conflict between CVS checkout and internal ActiveMQ operations

*Workaround*
You could try adding script task with a sleep command before the Checkout Task. A sleep of 5 minutes can be added for a start which can be later reduced if that works.
fields.summary: Bamboo build cancelled "it was marked as in progress but no agents were assigned to it."

fields.description:
When yo tried to perform the import using an archive, Bamboo throws an "unknown server error" with nothing shown in the logs. 

This is already fixed in Bamboo 5.2.1 and as such, you will need to upgrade your instance or alternatively upgrade the bamboo-jenkins plugin as thus:

# Download the attached version of the plugin which is 5.1
# Replace the current version in the {{atlassian-bamboo\WEB-INF\classes\atlassian-bundled-plugins.zip}} file
# Delete the current {{HOME/bundled-plugins}} directory
# Restart Bamboo
fields.summary: Importing jenkins from a zip archive not working in older versions of Bamboo

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a vulnerability in Bamboo which allowed unauthenticated users to commit actions on behalf of any other authorised user. In order to exploit this vulnerability, an attacker requires access to your Bamboo web interface. 

A Bamboo server is only vulnerable if it has been configured to be a part of an Application link with Trusted Applications authentication. This is not the default configuration.

The vulnerability affects all supported versions of Bamboo up to and including 5.2.1. It has been fixed in 5.2.2.

For more information, see our [security advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+Security+Advisory+2014-02-26].
fields.summary: Privilege escalation

However, if I provide the same argument using inline script, it executes correctly. I've already tried escaping the quotes, providing double quotes but none worked.

fields.description:
In Jenkins, there is a feature implemented via the locks and latches plugin where users can define "lock words" in plans so that whenever multiple plans have same lock words, only one of the plan can be run. This prevents parallel build of jobs in situations where we do not want to have build dependencies.

Latches on multiple plans on the otherhand will encourage parallel build of jobs
fields.summary: Implement locks and latches in Bamboo

fields.description:
Let's imagine I have an issue type like Business Requirements or Change Request. It has an "Approved for Deployment into Production" status. I would like to condition the deployment like this:

1) Link that requirement to the build, manually (I can do that, now)
2) If that issue is not in that status, then Bamboo won't let the user to deploy the related release
fields.summary: Prevent deployment of release if issues are not in the right status

fields.description: In some rare cases, during the deployment process, the duration will be "null". This however gives the corre ct value after thedeployment has finished. This in most cases happen when there is a timezone difference between the VM and the Bamboo server. Time difference between the client machine and server can also most likely cause this issue.
fields.summary: Deployment duration set as null during the progress

fields.description:
We have a plan that relies on simple artifact sharing (that is, not maven shared artifacts) between stages of the plan - the first stage builds the artifact, and every subsequent job of each stage afterwards relies on that artifact being present. Every few builds, this process fails.

We need this to be more reliable - if the artifact is not ready, don't start building the rest of the job.

If possible, we could mark tasks as requiring the shared artifact, so they block until it's available, but we can do other tasks beforehand (such as checking out a working copy of a repo) to keep agent utilization high.
fields.summary: Shared artifacts sometimes not copied before starting stage, breaking build

fields.description:
Remote agents have the ability to get their custom capabilities from the <home>/bin/bamboo-capabilities.properties file, however the local agent is not able to do the same thing.

I'm requesting that the local agent is able to also make use of the same file for the same purpose.
fields.summary: Local agent capabilities property file

fields.description: * Includes bundling the plugin so that it is available in OnDemand
fields.summary: Provide official support for the Variable Inject Plugin

fields.description:
Currently, unless you tweak the maven configurations on the build agents to reflect the way that atlas-compile or atlas-package work, the only reasonable way to have Bamboo build custom Atlassian plugins is to manually install the SDK, then use a command task to call directly to atlas-compile, atlas-package, etc.

It would be great to be able to install the Atlassian SDK through the plugin manager and have that expose the appropriate tasks for plugin developers. This would then allow a simple mechanism for keeping the SDK up to date within the Bamboo agents via the UPM.
fields.summary: Embed the Atlassian SDK in a Bamboo plugin

fields.description:
When selecting a remote agent to dedicate it to a specific deployment project/environment, if the project and/or the environment has a long name it seems to get merged into an unreadable text to fit into the combo box, under the "Dedicate Agent" tab or assigned environments page.

Pleas see the attached screenshot.
fields.summary: Long project/environment names are almost unreadable in the assigned environments page

fields.description:
If the repository checkout fails, the username and password are exposed in plain text on the web interface and in the logs.

To reproduce:

Environment: on-demand instance version 5.2-OD-4, Build 4004

# Create a plan that checks out a git repository using https with authentication.
# Run plan
# Do something to cause the Source Code Checkout task to fail. This may be simulated by changing the permissions of the build dir on the build server or by changing the network connectivity between the build server and the remote repository. I'm sure there are other scenarios as well that will cause the checkout to fail.
# Re-run plan.
fields.summary: Bamboo exposes username and password if Git checkout fails.

fields.description:
Amazon announced a bunch of new instance types today, and some of them look really awesome for builds.

The new C3 instance types are available now, and they have "per-core performance that bests that provided by any of the other EC2 instance types, at a price-performance ratio that will make them a great fit for many compute-intensive workloads". They also have SSDs, which I think will make a lot of builds much, much faster than with traditional EC2.

http://aws.typepad.com/aws/2013/11/a-generation-of-ec2-instances-for-compute-intensive-workloads.html

Also, they have an i2 instance type coming out soon which is an absolute BEAST: http://aws.typepad.com/aws/2013/11/coming-soon-the-i2-instance-type-high-io-performance-via-ssd.html . Would be amazing to be able to run these machines as well, although I think c3 is more important.
fields.summary: Support new C3 and I2 instance types in Elastic Bamboo

fields.description: We now have a security group "tag" for that, so it can be done safely.
fields.summary: When counting the uncontrolled instances, Bamboo should look only at the instances started by Bamboo servers

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
Resizing browser windows would cause some glitch on the header. Instead of showing *More* as one of the menu, it shows *aui.words.more* in the header. For more information, please refer to the following screenshot.
!resize-more.png!

*Steps to replicate*
# Access any Bamboo 5.2
# Resize the browser windows to pretty small size
fields.summary: Resizing browser windows will cause glitch

fields.description: At the moment, system variables are not configurable for the elastic agents. With feature, we can alter the agents memory allocation or add proxy settings
fields.summary: Make system variables configurable for the EC2 agent

fields.description:
When building something it is probable that several dependencies are required to build. Most times those dependencies are installed via packages. (RPMs, debs, etc)

If you are not using something like puppet to ensure that all bamboo agents have those depenencies, or you have some agents without those dependencies installed (for whatever reason), then setting up agent capabilities and job requirements is rather complex.

This is a request to add a "Package installed" requirement to jobs that would take a text string for the package name and an optional version number. Another optional field for the version comparison operator would be useful, but the general "greater than or equal to" would be a sufficient default.
fields.summary: Local and remote agent capability - installed RPM detection

fields.description:
The Screenshot: Specifying a Stash project in Bamboo in https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Integrating+Bamboo+with+Stash

shows a stash repo type.  That is not present in my installation.  

I have linked Bamboo and Stash with Basic Auth only, as suggested on the page, but still do not see the dropdown.  


I would love to be able to use stash repos, but can't seem
fields.summary: stash not available in repository type dropdown

fields.description:
It's currently possible to change the artifacts directory, working directory and build directory by editing the bamboo.cfg.xml file under <bamboo-home> directory. It's also possible to *view* this information under Bamboo Administration - > System Information. 

It will be great to be able to edit these paths from the UI. Bamboo can be paused when making the modifications and display a message requesting for a re-start when changes are saved.
fields.summary: The ability to modify artifacts and working/build directory from the UI

fields.description:
For a given agent, I have 1 custom capability defined:

variable_capability = 67890

For a given plan, I have 2 plan variables defined:

variable_plan = 12345 ${bamboo.capability.variable_capability} ${bamboo.other_variable_plan}

other_variable_plan = ABCDE

In that plan I have a single stage running a single job with only one script task executing:

echo %*

with the following arguments:

${bamboo.other_variable_plan} ${bamboo.capability.variable_capability} ${bamboo.variable_plan}

The result of execution I had with Bamboo 4.4.5:

ABCDE 67890 12345 67890 ABCDE 

The result of execution I now have with Bamboo 5.1.1:

ABCDE 67890 12345 ${bamboo.capability.variable_capability} ${bamboo.other_variable_plan}

Unless recursive variable resolution was a side effect in 4.4.5 I feel that this a bug in the new version.
fields.summary: Variable substitution within plan variables is not working.

fields.description:
With the latest Bamboo versions (using Tomcat - since 5.1.0), sometimes it takes about 15 seconds until Bamboo process gets killed after running stop-bamboo.sh. In some cases the process never ends, and a manual kill is required. 

This wasn't happening in older Bamboo versions, and "bambo.sh stop" immediately stopped Bamboo. Can we do something similar for the latest Bamboo versions?
fields.summary: Sometimes Bamboo doesn't stop after running stop-bamboo.sh

fields.description:
Branches for deployment projects are available since Bamboo version 5.2 - [https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-13268], but it still doesn't support feature branches (the ones that Bamboo automatically detects after the deployment project configuration is done). 

Please add the functionality to automatically trigger a deployment from an automatically created plan branch.
fields.summary: Automatically trigger deployment for an automatically created plan branch build

fields.description: Please remove test cases (from the TEST_CASE table) when the result is deleted. Even after all the results of a plan are removed the TEST_CASE table still doesn't shrink in size.
fields.summary: Expire unused test_case rows from the TEST_CASE table

fields.description:
h5. Symptoms:

After a Bamboo build is complete, a user would be presented with an error :

{code}
 Notifier Build Complete Action custom build post complete action failed to run
(java.lang.NullPointerException)
{code}

h5. Cause:

this is caused by a plugin called "notifier-bamboo-plugin" which is bundled in OnDemand only, and it's causing this issue. 

h5. Workaround:

Although this doesn't cause any harm, but if you want to get rid of the error message until the fix is released you can ask support to disable that function module in the plugin "notifier-bamboo-plugin".
fields.summary: Notification error Bamboo OnDemand

fields.description:
Over the last couple of weeks, we had to restart JBAC a couple of times because it was running out of heap memory and stuck doing full GCs. The last outage showed that the XMPP connections were sitting on around 1GB on memory. Despite the BambooSmackClient just used one connection, the other 531 (!) were still referenced by the other 531 InBandBytestreamManager instances and thus couldn't be cleaned up by the garbage collector (see the size of 532 of the manager map).

I've also attached the memory usage statistics of CBAC which doesn't use the IM server integration (/admin/instantmessagingserver/viewInstantMessagingServer.action). It uses much less memory.
fields.summary: XMPP connections leak memory

fields.description:
If a release is made from JIRA , choosing the "with new build" option, and the Bamboo plan triggers a deployment project, overridden Global variables show up twice under the deployment's variable tab, once with the overridden value and another time with the original value assigned to it when creating it. If I drop the variable by clicking the trash bin next to the variable name and choosing the option to override it again by clicking the pen icon, it appears correctly and only once. Please see the attached screenshots. 

It also shows up as undefined. I re-opened [Variable override during the release of JIRA version does not work|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-12766] since the same problem was reported for 5.0.1.
fields.summary: Global variables are listed twice when making a release from JIRA

fields.description:
OnDemand does not currently support [SSH transport for Git repositories|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-12228].

The option to select the 'SSH private key' option for 'Authentication Type' should not be visible until the above feature is implemented.

Affects Version: 5.2-OD-3  (not currently available in drop-down selections)
fields.summary: Git repository shows ssh on OnDemand when it is not available
Document Git and Mercurial differences regarding SSH on AOD

fields.description:
Normally Bamboo internal directory will not allow users to create groups with mixed-case or characters but the groups might come in from either CROWD or LDAP.

*Steps to replicate*
 # Create a directory in Crowd with group say "Dev-Team". Using mixed-case
 # Now associate a user to that group in crowd
 # Configure Bamboo to use crowd for user management using the above directory.
 # Bamboo will sync users and groups from the crowd directory
 # Now add global permissions on the group "dev-team". Bamboo will accept this even though the group name is really "Dev-Team". This can be alleviated with a fix of https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-14004

*Expected behavior*
The permission on that group should be respected

*Current behavior*
Permission not respected due to mixed-case.
fields.summary: Mixed-case group names breaks permissions in Bamboo

fields.description: When choosing groups in actions such as permissions, or notifications, it will be nice to make this auto complete similar to when picking users. This will be useful in situations where the group base is really big OR the group name is mixed-case.
fields.summary: Make the field auto-complete when choosing groups

fields.description:
Git plugin requires a REPOSITORY_GIT_AUTHENTICATION_TYPE property to be set, however the Jenkins plugin does not supply it.

Not sure if we should fix git or jenkins or both.
fields.summary: Jenkins plugin incompatible with latest Git plugin

fields.description:
We use the "Maven Dependencies Processor" for automatic dependency resolution and it works fine, as long as all artifacts/pom files are locally available. 

If we execute the Maven Dependencies Processor as first task on a bamboo agent which has a completely empty repository it is not able to download the required pom files. 

Or is this behavior expected and the dependencies processor should always be executed last?


How to reproduce :
- create a plan with a maven project checkout
- add the maven dependencies processor
- wipe the repository on the agent and run the plan
- it fails
- execute any random maven task BEFORE the processor, e.g. "mvn compile" so that the repository is full
- run the maven dependencies processor again and it works
fields.summary: Maven Dependencies Processor doesn't work if local repository is empty

fields.description:
The plan branch feature currently can override only the _default_ source repository. To make the plan branch useful in case there are multiple source repositories (that have the same svn trunk location as parent directory), the plan branch feature should be extended to substitute the trunk URL for the branch URL in all defined source repositories.

*Details on our use case:*
In our build plan, we have defined multiple source repositories, each of them is a subdirectory of the Trunk. This way we can take advantage of jobs doing building in parallel, and each job does an svn checkout only of what's needed to build. (The SVN tree contains more stuff than what is needed for a build.)

Our svn structure and corresponding source repo's look like:
-- trunk
---- DB (Bamboo repo 1 = SVNURL/trunk/DB)
---- OSB (Bamboo repo 2 = SVNURL/trunk/OSB)
---- SCA (Bamboo repo 3 = SVNURL/trunk/SCA)

Now we want to use the plan braching feature, in order to do a build on a previous release. In SVN we have a branches for each major version of our product. To execute the build correctly, all source locations must now point to the branch location. In case the branch is located at SVNURL/branches/R1.0, the source repositories must become the following:
Bamboo repo 1: SVNURL/branches/R1.0/DB)
Bamboo repo 2: SVNURL/branches/R1.0/OSB)
Bamboo repo 3: SVNURL/branches/R1.0/SCA)
fields.summary: Plan branch should be able to override multiple source repositories

fields.description:
If a job fails with test failures, you should have the option to only re-run the failed tests and not the entire job.

How could this be done? Well, I imagine as part of your plan configuration, you could specify extra options for rerunning failed tests. These options would simply get tacked on to the the maven task of your choice (via a dropdown).  Bamboo would provide you with a variable that contains a comma delimited list of the test classnames.

Essentially, I would add the config: -Dit.tests=$\{bamboo.failed.tests}

Then when I click rerun failed tests, bamboo puts this as a maven param and boom, my job now only reruns the failed tests, not the entire test suite.
fields.summary: Option to rerun only failed tests

fields.description:
When scheduled deploys are run, it creates a new release that is a copy of the latest release on file.  It appends on a (2), (3), etc to the name.  Why can't you just reuse the release like if I were doing it manually.  This way people reviewing the release can quickly see that we are all using same release vs different versions that might have different meta-data in them due to the release name??

At least give us a way to say we want to use the latest vs create a fresh one.  No one I know likes the current method.
fields.summary: Release Naming for Scheduled Deploys

fields.description:
When Bamboo queue fills up, it's not possible to add a new build unless we increase the number of parallel builds allowed and change the number of matching agents. The problem is, with more items queued, the most recent builds should wait in line to unit tests for a very long time. When, in fact, it might be better to let the most recent build jump in the line because it includes all of the other change sets from previous builds.
Please add a feature and/or provide an API, so build queue can be re-ordered and treated like a LIFO (stack).
fields.summary: Re-order the queue to run builds in a LIFO order

fields.description:
At the moment, as far as I understand the user name displayed in the UI (see attached UI capture) is hard-coded to ec2-user.

We are creating our own images and the user ec2-user is not necessarily created. This is confusing to our users as they need to remember what username to use based on the AMI name/type.

The purpose of this improvement is to have the ability to change this information in the AMI configuration page so the proper value could be displayed.
fields.summary: Allow configuration of user name in AMI definition
An unauthenticated user should be redirected to the login screen when trying to access artifacts

fields.description:
If a Git branch is deleted, the corresponding Bamboo plan branch is just disabled, not deleted.

We have a project with thousands of branches and, in the rare case that we need to reboot bamboo, it seems to reprocess all of these. As a result, bamboo takes nearly an hour to start.
fields.summary: Bamboo Plan Branches Aren't Deleted

fields.description:
System: Standalone on Windows Server 2008
RAM: 4.0 GB
System: Xeon CPU E5 2.40GHz
Database: MySQL

We're evaluating Bamboo and have a single Build plan with two Deployment Environments and a single remote agent, which is hardly ever running (there's only been 10 builds).  When the user isn't logged in, everything is fine. However, once a user is logged in, a lot of pages are really slow (minimum of 30 seconds per load).  

"My Bamboo" is the worst, but other pages, such as clicking a specific build link are slow as well.  The build agent isn't running and the bamboo server is the only thing running on this machine.  CPU usage is constantly low and there has hardly been any peaks.  Seems like something slow in the actual Bamboo page rendering.  I'm not sure if its MySQL related or a configuration issue.
fields.summary: Bamboo Very Slow for Logged in Users
